awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Quantum-Mechanical Investigation of Structure-Property Relationships in Organic Emitters for Efficient Thermally Activated Delayed Fluorescence (TADF)
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improve research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Clark Atlanta University has potential to broaden impacts in several areas. The use of computational methods to study light emitting diodes will result in an ability to predict the properties of these systems and increase performance through efficient design. The research will present an opportunity for undergraduate students to develop skills of scientific research and computational modeling. These skills will allow students to explore career opportunities in fields such as chemistry, materials, molecular modeling, computation and data science.

This project focuses on the theoretical characterization of purely organic electronic materials for efficient Thermally Activated Delayed Fluorescence (TADF). The goal is to develop novel organic materials for TADF-based Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLEDs). By using state-of-the-art theoretical and computational methodologies based on Density Functional Theory (DFT) applied with range-separated hybrid functionals, the research team will study the electronic and optical properties of carbazole-based donor-acceptor compounds as TADF organic emitters. The research team will develop: (1) a comprehensive description, at the molecular level, of the fundamental photophysical processes of TADF emitters; (2) a modeling protocol that can accurately describe the electronic structure of such emitters; (3) structure-property relationships; and provide theoretical guidelines for the design of new materials and/or selection of existing materials with well-defined properties leading to devices with improved performances. Thus, this project will contribute to the new materials development effort for displays in particular TADF-based OLEDs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Thermally Activated Delayed Fluorescence (TADF) appears as one of the most promising mechanisms to realize highly efficient Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLEDs) without the use of heavy transition metals and offers flexibility to fine-tune the electronic and optical properties of purely organic molecules. In this project, we explored quantum-chemical methods at the Density Functional Theory (DFT) level to characterize the excited-state properties of purely organic TADF emitters with a donor-acceptor combination in the molecular architecture. The molecules modelled included carbazole and its derivatives as a donor and several acceptors including dicyanobenzenes, diphenylsulfones, triazines, and oxadiazoles which are commonly used in the design of purely organic donor-acceptor-type TADF emitters. We found that DFT by using an optimally-tuned (OT) Range-Separated-Hybrid (RSH) functional can be used for a reliable description of the singlet and triplet excited states in terms of their relative energy and detailed nature (such as contributions from charge-transfer and local excitations) in the case of donor-acceptor-type materials for thermally activated delayed fluorescent devices.

Furthermore, we incorporated the solid-state effects in the modeling scheme through the use of a Screened RSH method which allows to include the dielectric medium by modifying the partition of the Coulomb interaction in the RSH functional. Based on this method, we identified new materials with interesting properties that control their TADF emission. For instance, theoretical calculations revealed the importance of the intramolecular non-covalent interactions in the form of pi-pi interactions that facilitate TADF in the case of diphenyl sulfoxide-based emitters. Same theoretical methodology was used to describe the excited-state energetics and nature of the 2-methyl-5-(penta(9-car-bazolyl)phenyl)-3,4,5-oxadizole derivatives and produced the key TADF parameters such as the rates of the radiative transitions and spin-orbit-coupling constants that shed light on the experimental findings. Part of the results were published in the Journal of Physical Chemistry A (Cooper et al., 2022) and distributed at several conferences featuring organic-based electroluminescent materials for display, lighting and future photonic applications (e.g., MRS Fall/Spring 2020, MRS 2023 Spring Meeting Symposia, ACS Spring 2022 meeting). This project is also featured in a science communication magazine, Scientia, in 2022 for the broader audience. The researchers were also invited to present their results at interdisciplinary venues and many other peer-reviewed publications and scientific presentations are anticipated.

In this project, constant and effective theoretical and modeling allowed us to understand the electronic and optical properties of various classes of purely organic single molecule TADF materials. We demonstrated that our approach can be used to study the charge-transfer excited states of other donor-acceptor-type systems as they are commonly present in the active layers of next generation optoelectronic devices such as exciplexes in TADF-based OLEDs or bulk heterojunction of organic solar cells. Our findings and continuous improvement of the underlying theory resulted in the development of new research dierctions which received external funding during the lifespan of this project.

The project’s findings allowed establishing guidelines for the selection of high-performance materials based on computational results. Such a knowledge-centered approach is expected to yield novel materials for the realization of devices with improved design and better performances. This project also enabled the development of the research capacity in computational materials chemistry at Clark Atlanta University through resources that form the infrastructure, partnerships, and training of students and a postdoctoral associate. Five undergraduate students including Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) summer students had participated in the project. Students participating in this project presented their results at various meetings and symposiums (e.g., Student Data Science Symposium organized by Atlanta University Center (AUC) Data Science Initiative (DSI) in 2022 and 2023). The PI also delivered lightning talks at the W.E.B Du Bois Data Science Symposium in the same years.

The research findings were also incorporated in instructional materials. The PI developed new courses, Introduction to Materials Science and Materials Characterization, where illustrative examples from this research project and techniques were incorporated in the course materials. The project also created professional development resources through research and education. The researchers completed online certification courses to level up their skillset in molecular modeling, programming and data analysis.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2024
Modified by: Seyhan Salman

Image
  • Electronic structure calculations of oxadiazole derivatives that emit via thermally activated delayed fluorescence.
    Ajith Ashokan
    Copyrighted
    Seyhan Salman
    Molecular Structures and Mechanism of Thermally Activated Delayed Luminescence
por.por_txt_cntn:
Thermally Activated Delayed Fluorescence (TADF) appears as one of the most promising mechanisms to realize highly efficient Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLEDs) without the use of heavy transition metals and offers flexibility to fine-tune the electronic and optical properties of purely organic molecules. Furthermore, we incorporated the solid-state effects in the modeling scheme through the use of a Screened RSH method which allows to include the dielectric medium by modifying the partition of the Coulomb interaction in the RSH functional. Based on this method, we identified new materials with interesting properties that control their TADF emission. We demonstrated that our approach can be used to study the charge-transfer excited states of other donor-acceptor-type systems as they are commonly present in the active layers of next generation optoelectronic devices such as exciplexes in TADF-based OLEDs or bulk heterojunction of organic solar cells. Our findings and continuous improvement of the underlying theory resulted in the development of new research dierctions which received external funding during the lifespan of this project.


The projects findings allowed establishing guidelines for the selection of high-performance materials based on computational results. Such a knowledge-centered approach is expected to yield novel materials for the realization of devices with improved design and better performances. This project also enabled the development of the research capacity in computational materials chemistry at Clark Atlanta University through resources that form the infrastructure, partnerships, and training of students and a postdoctoral associate. Five undergraduate students including Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) summer students had participated in the project. Students participating in this project presented their results at various meetings and symposiums (e.g., Student Data Science Symposium organized by Atlanta University Center (AUC) Data Science Initiative (DSI) in 2022 and 2023).
